item.title: The Case for Persona 4 Revival to Go Fully Open-World
item.description:
Persona 4 Revival was officially announced last month, though this was more like a confirmation of life than a proper reveal. Despite there being very little info unveiled about this Persona 4 remake yet, the success of Atlus' most recent remake projects, like RAIDOU Remastered: Mystery of the Soulless Army and Persona 3 Reload, serve as reasons for optimism.

Indeed, Atlus has been knocking its remakes out of the park, keeping them just as faithful to their originals as necessary, while implementing a number of smart, modern touches. In the case of Persona 3 Reload , this manifested in an expert recreation of the original Persona 3 's atmosphere, tone, and heart-wrenching narrative, for instance. In the case of Persona 4 Revival , there are a handful of similarly crucial aspects for Atlus and P-Studio to get right, and the game's charming world might just be chief among them. Inaba is often cited as one of the best, most vibrant settings of any Megaten game, and while Persona 4 Revival will surely strive to faithfully recreate the sleepy small town, it shouldn't be afraid to get a bit more ambitious.

More Than Any Other Persona Setting, Inaba Makes Sense as a Seamless Open-World

Persona 4 Isn't a 'True' Open-World

Just like other Persona games, Persona 4 's Inaba can only be called an open-world setting in the loosest sense of the term. Yes, players can technically go where they please, but the compartmentalized nature of the game's map makes Inaba feel more like a series of hub or activity areas, akin to something like the Mass Effect trilogy's approach to world design. There's no sense of immersive freedom while exploring, as each area feels disconnected from each other rather than just part of a frictionless whole.

In other Persona games, this sort of level design makes sense. For example, Persona 5 is set in Tokyo, with disparate locations often being separated by subway trips, and the archipelago-style map design fits the nature of the urban setting. Persona 4 , on the other hand, is meant to take place in an intimate, tight-knit, cozy town, but the level design clashes with this premise. The opportunity to fully experience Inaba as a complete, continuous game world would buttress the setting's essential traits, while also making for a more compelling and immersive gameplay experience.

Persona 4 Revival Could Shake Up the Persona Formula with an Open-World

Implementing more traditional open-world design tendencies would have knock-on benefits for the rest of Persona 4 Revival as well. Much like how the Yakuza games manage to cram a bevy of content into the small, dense neighborhood of Kamurocho, so too could Persona 4 Revival make Inaba feel like more of a living, plausible environment. There could be secrets to uncover in every nook and cranny, dark alleys to venture down, and even charismatic NPCs to assist. If Persona 4 Revival 's version of Inaba were more like one cohesive space, and less like a series of disconnected, purpose-built rooms, then the potential for exploration and engaging side content could shoot through the roof.

Persona 3 Reload felt like Persona 3 with the resources and modern design tendencies of Persona 5 ; Persona 4 Revival could be something greater. It could take a bigger swing at polishing and remixing the key ingredients of the Persona formula, rather than just playing it safe and sticking to what works. With the intentionally small-scale, quaint setting of Persona 4 seeming tailor-made for the condensed open-world format, and with the Persona franchise skewing toward urban environments rather than rural ones, this might be Atlus' only chance to experiment with such world design for a while.

item.title: D&D's Eberron: Forge of the Artificer is Technically Bringing Back Half-Elves
item.description:
The 2024 rules refresh for Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition was an eventful time for the TTRPG. Nearly every aspect of the game received a facelift in this update, from classes and spells to monsters and feats. Playable species – formerly known as races – also changed drastically, including the addition of two new core options with the Aasimar and Goliath. However, one of the most popular Dungeons and Dragons species was conspicuously absent from the updated Player's Handbook : the Half-Elf.

The reason for this was straightforward; rather than having specific stats for mixed-heritage characters like Half-Elves or Half-Orcs in the new Dungeons and Dragons rules, players could simply borrow core traits from the species of their parents to create a personalized blend. However, these guidelines were unsatisfactory for some, as most species traits are not balanced against each other, easily enabling over- and under-powered combinations. Apparently, some part of Wizards of the Coast agreed – despite their initial position, Half-Elves are set to appear in Eberron: Forge of the Artificer , albeit under a different name: the Khoravar.

The Khoravar – Half-Elves of Eberron in D&D

In Khorvaire – the main continent in the world of Eberron – people with both Human and Elvish ancestry are called Khoravar. Sometimes referred to as "the children of Khorvaire," they are one of the most populous species on the continent, and can be found virtually everywhere either of their parent races live. Khoravar are commonplace enough that they can manifest hereditary dragonmarks that are vital to the Dungeons and Dragons world, such as the Mark of the Storm of House Lyrandar and the Mark of Detection of House Medani.

But despite their special name, Khoravar are literally Half-Elves; both the Eberron wiki and Keith Baker, creator of the setting, refer to them as such. Beyond the obvious differences in their culture, there is fundamentally nothing different from a Khoravar and a Half-Elf from the Forgotten Realms or Greyhawk.

Even their species traits are similar in some ways to the original Half-Elf from the 2014 Player’s Handbook . Both have Darkvision, Fey Ancestry, and Skill Versatility – though the OG Half-Elf version grants two skills, while the Khoravar’s manifests as one skill or tool that can be changed every day. They are further differentiated by the Half-Elf’s +1 bonus to a third characteristic, while the Khoravar get a free, changeable Cleric, Druid, or Wizard cantrip and resistance to being rendered Unconscious, both of which are traits drawn from their Elvish parents.

Khoravar Traits (Eberron: Forge of the Artificer) vs. Half-Elf Traits (PHB 2014)

Khoravar

Half-Elf

Darkvision 60 ft.

Darkvision 60 ft.

Fey Ancestry (Advantage against Charmed)

Fey Ancestry (Advantage against Charmed)

Skill Versatility (Proficiency in one skill or tool, changeable daily)

Skill Versatility (Proficiency in two skills)

+2 to one characteristic, +1 to another

+2 Charisma, +1 to two other characteristics

Fey Gift (One Cleric, Druid, or Wizard cantrip, changeable daily)

Optional rule to replace Skill Versatility with a Wizard cantrip

Lethargy Resistance (Succeed on save against Unconscious once every 1d4 days)

-

Unfortunately, despite all of this, Khoravar are still technically a setting-specific species. Because they do not appear in the Player’s Handbook , a dungeon master would be well within their rights to forbid their use. Even Dungeons and Dragons ' blog about Eberron: Forge of the Artificer referred to the Khoravar as “a unique playable species in the world of Eberron.”

That said, adapting the Khoravar to other settings seems like the most elegant approach to letting fans play Half-Elves in the new Dungeons and Dragons rules. While players could technically still use the “pick traits from each parent” method, the new option in D&D 's Eberron: Forge of the Artificer sourcebook is a more balanced, consistent, and straightforward method of playing them.

However, the addition of the Khoravar begs the question: what about Half-Orcs? While Half-Elves are a fan-favorite species in Dungeons and Dragons – so much so that they were one of the most popular races in Baldur’s Gate 3 – Half-Orcs were in the original Player’s Handbook as well, even though most of their traits were simply transferred over to the new core Orc option. The Khoravar have technically opened up a floodgate that was supposed to stay closed in the 2024 Dungeons and Dragons rules, so maybe Half-Orcs will get the same treatment some day.

item.title: Umamusume: All Positive and Negative Conditions, Explained
item.description:
There are multiple random events in Umamusume: Pretty Derby 's career mode, and some of them afflict your trainee with various conditions. Most of these are injuries or negative status effects that hinder your Umamusume 's training, but some conditions are actually helpful and make things a lot easier.

There are a few things you can do to influence the conditions that show up during your Umamusume career runs, but things are ultimately left up to chance. Even something as simple as resting — which every character needs to do eventually — can result in a negative status effect that you need to deal with. Here are all the conditions you can encounter in Umamusume: Pretty Derby , both good and bad.

All Umamusume Conditions and How to Fix Them

These are all the positive and negative conditions your trainee can get in Umamusume :

Condition

Effects

How to Get

How to Remove

Practice Poor

Increases training failure chance by 2%.

Training Failure

Infirmary

Migraine

Cannot increase mood.

Random

Infirmary

Dry Skin

Random chance to lower mood every turn.

Random

Infirmary

Insomnia

Random chance to lower energy by 10 every turn.

Rest

Infirmary or recovering 70 energy from Rest.

Slow Metabolism

Prevents Speed stat growth.

Random

Infirmary

Slacker

Random chance for trainee to skip selected training.

Random

Infirmary or training with Etsuko Otonashi (if your trainee shows up).

Under the Weather

Increases training failure chance by 2%. (Super Creek only.)

Participate in the Sumire Stakes race.

Participate in the Kikka Sho race.

Charming

Increases friendship gain by 2.

Random

-

Fast Learner

Reduces skill costs by 10%.

Random

-

Practice Perfect

Reduces training failure chance by 4%.

Random

-

Hot Topic

Increases friendship gain with Director Akikawa and Etsuko Otonashi by 40%.

Random

-

Shining Brightly

Reduces training failure chance. (Super Creek only.)

Remove Under the Weather by participating in the Kikka Sho race.

-

Most conditions in Umamusume: Pretty Derby can be removed with a visit to the Infirmary, but even then, a single Infirmary trip isn't a guarantee that your trainee will heal. Sometimes, you'll have to waste two or three turns to fix your Umamusume's condition. Some conditions (like Slacker) are basically run killers, so be careful.

Some conditions are exclusive to certain Umamusume, such as Super Creek's Shining Brightly buff. Keep that in mind when choosing your next career trainee.

Conditions are an important part of Umamusume 's career mode, and they can make or break your run if you encounter them. If you get a good condition like Fast Learner or Hot Topic, you'll have a much greater chance of winning races and making it all the way to the URA Finale.

5 Images
5 Images

item.title: Fallout 5’s Rumored Greenlight May Be the Final Nail in the Coffin for Starfield
item.description:
Fallout 5 has gotten the go ahead, according to recent rumors. Jez Cordon of Windows Central reports that Zenimax has approved the start of development for Fallout 5 , potentially at the expense of Project Blackbird , an MMO project from the team behind The Elder Scrolls Online . Assuming these claims are accurate, the next few years should be rather interesting for Bethesda fans.

Of course, news of Fallout 5 kicking off development in earnest is exciting, since the franchise hasn't seen a proper, single-player entry in nearly a decade now, though this lapse in releases also makes Fallout 5 something of a given; everyone knew that Bethesda would be getting back to the Fallout franchise sooner or later. Even so, the timing of this alleged tip-off is curious, as it comes during a time of uncertainty at Bethesda Game Studios: Starfield , the supposed next great step from the developer, hasn't even been out for two years, and many have expected it to remain one of Bethesda's top priorities for many years to come. But this optimistic vision of Starfield 's future is faltering, and Fallout 5 could deliver the finishing blow.

With Bethesda Moving On to Fallout 5, Will There Be Room for Starfield?

Starfield Support Has Slowed, and Fallout 5 Could Bring It to a Complete Halt

Bitter as it may be to admit, Starfield hasn't had the cultural or financial impact that Xbox and Bethesda hoped that it would. It has its fans, no doubt, but it's not the Game-Awards-sweeping, hotcake-selling phenomenon that many hoped it would be. It certainly doesn't touch the significance or acclaim of something like Skyrim or Fallout 3 , though there is still some hope that Bethesda will right the ship via free content drops and ambitious DLC. However, such hope is dwindling rapidly, as Starfield isn't having a crazy comeback by any means.

The Shattered Space DLC was perhaps the first nail in the coffin for Starfield optimism. Early patches, specifically the REV-8, sparked a great deal of excitement within the game's fanbase, setting a high bar for the game's first premium expansion. Sadly, Starfield has ostensibly been on ice since: Bethesda has stated that it has big plans for Starfield in 2025, but that was several months ago, and the studio has made nary a peep about the game. With Shattered Space 's negative reception, there's been some speculation that Bethesda will simply abandon Starfield 's DLC prospects, as they may no longer be worth the investment, though no concrete conclusions can be drawn about such content at the moment.

The June 2025 Xbox Games Showcase would have been the most likely time for Bethesda to draw back the curtain on Starfield 's future, but the game never made an appearance.

All of this is to say that the rumored development of Fallout 5 isn't occurring in a vacuum: it's arrived in the wake of a troubled Bethesda Game Studios launch. It's not just that Fallout 5 may divert resources from Starfield , but that it would make fiscal sense to do so.

Fallout is on fire at the moment, with Fallout 76 surviving against the odds and the Fallout TV show giving the IP more prestige than ever; Starfield is ice-cold, unlikely to ignite the passions of gamers at large any time soon. Fallout 5 is likely viewed as a surefire success by ZeniMax and Microsoft both, and after the cloud of pessimism that has followed Starfield , Bethesda developers may be ready to move on to something a bit more familiar, with better optics.

Your comment has not been saved

Starfield is the first new universe in 25 years from Bethesda Game Studios, the award-winning creators of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and Fallout 4. In this next generation role-playing game set amongst the stars, create any character you want and explore with unparalleled freedom as you embark on an epic journey to answer humanity’s greatest mystery.
The year is 2330. Humanity has ventured beyond our solar system, settling new planets, and living as a spacefaring people. From humble beginnings as a space miner, you will join Constellation – the last group of space explorers seeking rare artifacts throughout the galaxy – and navigate the vast expanse of the Settled Systems in Bethesda Game Studios’ biggest and most ambitious game.

item.title: Eriksholm: The Stolen Dream - All Notes and Collectibles in Chapter 1
item.description:
A lot of players will look for games that are rich in things to hunt for, and Eriksholm: The Stolen Dream features notes and collectibles throughout it. Players can open up their inventory to check through their notes, collectibles, and their current objective at any time. Using current objectives is a great way of knowing when a player is closing in on an area where they can pick up one of these notes and/or collectibles.

Players can also use unique landmarks and objects to better navigate them. These notes and collectibles will add to the rich lore of the game, and many of them aid the game in building a rich and atmospheric world setting. This guide will ensure players find every note and collectible for Chapter 1 of Eriksholm: The Stolen Dream

All Notes in Eriksholm: The Stolen Dream

Since the game uses an isometric view with a camera that can be rotated, saying “to the left/right," might not be true for all players while they are playing. This guide will use markers to help players navigate to other key markers so that they don’t end up going in the wrong direction. At times, it may ask players to rotate the camera at certain points so that the screen aligns to a position where they can be more easily navigated.

If players feel they are in the vicinity of a note but do not see it, rotate the camera to reveal parts of the map that are concealed and wait a moment for the note to shimmer.

Number

Note Name

Objective

Description

1

Note in the Boiler Room - A note from one colleague to another.

Reach the rooftop ladder

Players will start by crawling into the boiler room. Here, they will receive some dialogue, and their objective to escape the building will be updated to reach the rooftop ladder. Players will see the light of the furnace and a wheelbarrow heading away from the furnace. In the same direction, there will be a table with a tea kettle on it. The note can be found on this tea kettle. Collectible 1 is also in this room.

2

Alva’s Reach - A thank-you letter.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

Players will progress through the workshop and exit onto some rooftops. This will update their objective. You will move onto a rooftop with the “citizens of Eriksholm” banner on it. Drop from the opposite side of this roof and run along the walls. You will walk over some planks to another rooftop. Head straight from these planks to find the next note at the end of the path. Collectible 2 is near this note.

3

Official Ledger - An official ledger with shipping notices. Many of the are crossed out.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

From collectible 2 (see below), head back to the two ladders, but do not go up them. Players will see a group of birds they can use to distract an enemy. There will also be a gate next to these birds. Vault over this gate, and the Note will be on the other side.

4

Map of Cutter’s Hill - A detailed map of Cutter’s Hill, used by the authorities to plan and allocate resources.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

After the cutscene where the officer turns and the player needs to run to a yellow house, there will be a fork. Take the path with the wooden bridge to find the Note sitting on a barrel.

5

The Heartpox - A page froma medical journal.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

Vault over the wall next to Note 4 and look through the gate to see the next note and the vent to get into this building. Rotate the camera to align the position of the grate to see it glimmer. Enter this gate and pick up this Note. Collectible 3 is in the same room.

6

An Official Letter - Letter from the office running the workforce in the Cutter’s Hill domestic Area.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

After leaving the previous area by avoiding the guards, players will vault over a wooden fence and find some stairs leading up. This Note is at the bottom of these stairs, and players may need to rotate their camera to see it. This Note is near Collectible 4.

7

Police Report

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

Head back to the planks past the stone steps and rotate the camera, so your character is on the right side of the screen. Look at the building with the boarded-up windows. Against this building there will be a table. Wait a moment to see the Note shimmer.

8

Cutter’s Hill in the Past—Woodworking - Part of an article from a newspaper about woodworking in Cutter’s Hill.

Cross the Drawbridge

Past the checkpoint that updates the objective to Find a New Way to Leave Cutter’s Hill . Players will head up some stone steps. Players will see some plants pressed up against a wall and some steps going up. Hug the wall on the character’s left side as they go up these steps. This will lead them up 2 more sets of steps and through an open gate. The Note is on a crate past this gate. Collectible 5 is near this Note.

9

Map of Rosmark - An old map of Rosmark Country.

Cross the Drawbridge

Progress to the next checkpoint. There will be a wooden bridge leading to a large poster of Mayor Hansen. This Note can be found on a crate to the right of this large poster.

10

Personal Letter - A personal letter, attached to a schedule.

Cross the Drawbridge

Climb up the ladder to the right of the poster of the Mayor. Rotate the screen left until the poster is out of view. Look below the “Citizens of Eriksholm” banner to see the Note on top of a crate. You may need to wait a moment for it to shimmer.

11

Cutter’s Hill in the Past—Sails - A note on Sails.

Cross the Drawbridge

Backtrack to the roof and head to the opposite side of the ladder next to the Mayor’s poster. You will find this Note in the corner of the roof.

12

Cutter’s Hill in the Past—Glass - Part of an article from a newspaper about glassmaking in Cutter’s Hill.

Escape Through East Gate

Head down the ladder by Note 11 and lower the drawbridge. Cross the drawbridge to update the objective and floor the metal tracks on the floor to some parked carts. With the player character looking at these carts while standing behind them, you will see some stairs going down on their right side. Go down these steps, and you will see a Note shimmering on top of a barrel.

13

Food Ticket - A Rossmark Food Administration subvention ticket, all slots used.

Escape Through East Gate

After picking up Note 12, turn the camera so that you can see the front of the building with the stone steps on its left. You will see some ledges to the right of this building. Climb up these ledges and head straight until you see some tables with plates on them. Note 13 is sitting on a barrel near these tables.

14

A Postcard - A postcard for a woman named Ilse from the Apple Gardens.

Escape Through East Gate

Slide open both gates near Note 13. Go through the second slide gate to see Note 14 sitting next to a potted plant.

15

Fishterman’s Rest - A note on life in Fisherman’s Rest

Escape Through East Gate

After getting Note 14, go down the ladder to get to the docks. Head along the docks to the other side, where players will see some coffins. You will find some stairs leading up to where the next Note will be.

16

Green Rock Smuggler - Part of a police report.

Escape Through East Gate

Head opposite the way you came to find some stairs going down to the very corner of the docks. Near a crane above the water will be a barrel with Note 16 on top of it.

17

Train Ticket - A train ticket. Eriksholm—Apple Gardens station

Hide on the Train

Be sure to get Collectible 6 before heading to the train. Once players reach the train, they can drop onto the wooden planks along the cliffside. On the opposite side will be a metal ladder, and the final Note.

The Heartpox entry is actually misspelled in the game, saying “froma medical journal” instead of “from a medical journal.” Not all mistakes that make it into video games need to be a glitch.

All Collectibles in Eriksholm: The Stolen Dream

In addition to all these Notes, there are also 6 collectibles to pick up as players make their way through Chapter 1.

Number

Collectible Name

Objective

Description

1

Eriksholm Postcard - A postcard of Eriksholm.

Reach the rooftop ladder

Directly opposite the furnace door and wheelbarrow will be a wall. Up on this wall will be collectible 1.

2

Apple Gardens Brochure - The cover of a pamphlet that details travelling to the Apple Gardens.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

Adjacent to the path between the planks and this note will be a wall. Vault over this wall and head up the steps. Vault over the wooden gate and then up onto the roof with the water tower on it. Climb down both ladders and head to the opposite side of the street where you will find some stairs going down. Players will see a large yellow silo with the number 69 on it. Just past this silo will be a ladder to a platform with this collectible sitting on a table.

3

Madame Cecilia, An ad for a travelling theatre company.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

This collectible can be found in the same room as Note 5, The Heartpox.

4

Evergreen South - A postcard from a train station.

Get to Cobbler’s Gate

Backtrack and go over the wooden gate you used to get to Note 4. Head straight, and you will find a platform with white paint to jump down from. Follow the wooden planks and head down the stone steps. Before heading across the next set of wooden planks, turn away from the bushes and follow the path. Go under the archway and there will be the collectible sitting on top of a crate.

5

Retail Catalogue - A catalog with seeds for various plants.

Cross the Drawbridge

From Note 8, turn the camera so that the path you came from is on the right. Head left and go down the stone steps. Head down and then left again to find the next Note.

6

Rosmark Produce, LTD. - An ad for a local grocery chain.

Escape Through East Gate

Near the end of the chapter, players will find a large yellow building with blue flags adored with yellow lions hanging from it. Head into the ally away from the road with the tracks. Just past this building will be a man unpacking the back of a truck. The final collectible is just past this truck.

This game is a true treasure, and many players will be reminded about A Plague's Tale while playing it.

Powered by
